revision.comment: /* Later years */ showed which bridge was renamed for Robert Rader
revision.text:
{{Infobox military person | name = Robert J. Rader | caption = | rank = [[File:US Army WWII SSGT.svg|25px]] [[Staff Sergeant]] | unit = [[File:506 patch.jpeg|30px]] [[E Company, 506th Infantry Regiment (United States)|Easy Company]], 2nd [[Battalion]], [[506th Parachute Infantry Regiment]],
[[File:US 101st Airborne Division patch.svg|30px]][[101st Airborne Division]] | nickname = -''Bob''
-''Rook'' | birth_date = {{birth date|1923|10|09|mf=yes}} | death_date = {{death date and age|1997|04|07|1923|10|09|mf=yes}} | birth_place = [[Manchester, Ohio]], United States | allegiance = {{USA}} | branch = [[United States Army]] | serviceyears = 1942-1945 |battles = [[World War II]] * [[Operation Overlord|Battle of Normandy]] *[[Operation Market Garden]] *[[Battle of the Bulge]] | relations = -Lucille Rader (widow)
-Donald Rader (son)
-Robin Rader (daughter) | laterwork = Teacher }} [[Staff sergeant]] '''Robert Rader''' (October 9, 1923 â€“ April 7, 1998) was a [[non-commissioned officer]] with [[E Company, 506th Infantry Regiment (United States)|Easy Company]], 2nd [[Battalion]], [[506th Parachute Infantry Regiment]], in the [[101st Airborne Division]] of the [[United States Army#20th century|United States Army]] during [[World War II]]. Rader was one of the 140 Toccoa men of Easy Company. Rader's life story was featured in the 2010 book ''A Company of Heroes: Personal Memories about the Real Band of Brothers and the Legacy They Left Us''. ==Youth== Rader was born in Manchester, Ohio. He enlisted in the Ohio National Guard when he was 16. He was given an honorable discharge although he was discovered to be underage. He graduated from high school in 1942.{{harvp|Brotherton|2010|p=138}} ==Military service== Rader enlisted in the army and volunteered for paratrooper with two hometown friends, [[Donald Hoobler]] and [[William Howell (soldier)|William Howell]]. The three were sent to Camp Toccoa and became three of the 140 original Toccoa men of Easy Company, and trained under [[Captain (United States O-3)|Captain]] [[Herbert Sobel]]. The three called themselves ''three hillbillies'' because they were all country boys. They also befriended [[William Dukeman]]. Rader made his first combat jump into [[Normandy]] on [[D-Day]]. He also participated in the [[Operation Market Garden]] in September 17, 1944 in the [[Netherlands]]. He was squad leader of 1st Platoon's 3rd Squad.{{harvp|Ooms|2013|p=51}} Rader also participated in the [[Battle of the Bulge]] in [[Bastogne]]. On Christmas Eve, Rader and Hoobler volunteered for outpost duty as a Christmas present to their comrades.{{harvp|Brotherton|2010|p=141}} Rader fought with his unit until the end of the war. He was discharged in November 1945. Rader was awarded medals including 2 [[Bronze Stars]] for his actions.{{harvp|Brotherton|2010|p=142}} ==Later years== Rader obtained his bachelor's degree in education in Cedarville College in Ohio. He became a teacher and taught the handicapped at Paso Robles High School in California for more than thirty years.{{harvp|Ambrose|1992|loc=Chapter 19}} He met Lucille when he was in California and the two got married in February 14, 1953.{{harvp|Brotherton|2010|p=143}} Rader died on April 7, 1997. A few years after his death, the people of Paso Robles had the 13th Street bridge over the [[Salinas River]] renamed the Robert J. Rader Memorial Bridge in Rader's honor. ==References== {{Reflist|24em}} {{Portal|Biography|United States Army|World War II}} ===Bibliography=== {{refbegin}} *{{cite book |last=Ambrose |first=Stephen E. |year=1992 |title=Band of Brothers: Easy Company, 506th Regiment, 101st Airborne from Normandy to Hitler's Eagle's Nest |publisher=Simon & Schuster |isbn=978-0-7434-6411-6 |ref=harv}} *{{cite book |last=Brotherton |first=Marcus |year=2010 |title=A Company of Heroes: Personal Memories about the Real Band of Brothers and the Legacy They Left Us |publisher=Berkley Caliber |isbn=978-0-425-23420-4 |ref=harv}} *{{cite book |last=Ooms |first=Ronald |year=2013 |title=Silver Eagle: The Official Biography of 'Band of Brothers' Veteran [[Clancy Lyall]] |publisher=Pneuma Springs Publishing |isbn=9781782282648 |ref=harv}} {{refend}} {{Band of Brothers (miniseries)}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Rader, Robert}} [[Category:American military personnel of World War II]] [[Category:Band of Brothers characters]] [[Category:Recipients of the Bronze Star Medal]] [[Category:Recipients of the Silver Star]] [[Category:United States Army soldiers]] [[Category:Operation Overlord people]] [[Category:1921 births]] [[Category:1997 deaths]]
